Docs.summary: Represents a column that hosts controls in its cells.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridCheckBoxColumn> to display columns of Boolean data as a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.CheckBox>. The following illustration shows an example of <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridCheckBoxColumn>.
![A DataGridCheckBox column](~/add/media/wpf-datagrid-checkbox.png "A DataGridCheckBox column")
To populate the column, bind the column to the data by using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridBoundColumn.Binding%2A> property. The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridBoundColumn.Binding%2A> property is applied to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.CheckBox> element created in the column. The <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.DataContext%2A> for the element in each cell is the data item for the row the cell is in. Therefore, to set up the binding you only have to set the <xref:System.Windows.Data.Binding.Path%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>. Optionally, you can specify a <xref:System.Windows.Data.Binding.Converter%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> if your data source and target are different types. For more information about data binding, see [Data Binding (WPF)](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-wpf.md).
You can customize the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridCheckBoxColumn> by setting properties, such as <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridColumn.Width%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridColumn.Header%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridCheckBoxColumn.IsThreeState%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridColumn.IsReadOnly%2A>.
If you want to display other types of data, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGrid> provides the following column types:
|Column Type|Data Display| |-----------------|------------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridHyperlinkColumn>|Use to display URI data.| |<xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridComboBoxColumn>|Use to display enumeration data.| |<xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridTextColumn>|Use to display text.|
If you want to use other controls in your <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGrid>, you can create your own column types by using <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridTemplateColumn>.
## Examples The following example shows how to add a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridCheckBoxColumn>. This example uses a database as the source and displays a column of Boolean data.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridCheckBoxColumn.IsThreeState%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property lets you use a nullable Boolean as the data type and has the same functionality as the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.ToggleButton.IsThreeState%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property on <xref:System.Windows.Controls.CheckBox>.
The three states for the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.ToggleButton.IsChecked%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.CheckBox> control are `true`, `false`, and `null`.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGrid> control calls the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridColumn.PrepareCellForEdit%2A> method when a cell in a column derived from <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridColumn> enters editing mode. The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridCheckBoxColumn> class overrides this method to respond immediately to the user gesture by updating the value in the hosted <xref:System.Windows.Controls.CheckBox> control. This immediate response is necessary because a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DataGridCheckBoxColumn> cell enters edit mode with the same user gesture that changes the state of its hosted <xref:System.Windows.Controls.CheckBox>.
